text.p: Blackburn Rovers, bottom of the English premier league without a win this season, have parted company with manager Ray Harford.

Harford, who resigned, had been under increasing pressure since taking over from Kenny Dalglish last season. He decided he could take no more following Tuesday's 1-0 home defeat by second division Stockport in the League Cup third round.
There was a demonstration against him by Blackburn fans, who in 1995 celebrated the club's winning of the championship under Dalglish.

Harford, who took over the managership after being coach under Dalglish, said: "It was a big decision that's taken a lot of thought, but the performance and result against Stockport the other night was the final straw."

Blackburn chairman Robert Coar said: "Ray has offered his resignation and that has been accepted by the board of Blackburn Rovers. We have negotiated a settlement with Ray in view of his five years stout, sterling and loyal service.
"We wish him and his wife Maureen all the best for the future."
